ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
How to conduct a policy recommendation project. 
Knowledge: protracted refugee situations in East Africa
Skills: interviewing, literature review, policy writing

How to conduct interviews, extract policy recommendations from interviews, and prioritize strands of research within a broad area of focus. How to interact with IGO clients and tailor policy recommendations appropriately. Research on protracted refugee situations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths
- Very intense and interesting

Weaknesses
- No guidance on how to create a good methodology using interviews as primary source
- No teaching on how to write for policy recommendations

Strengths: unique opportunity to take on an applied project for a client (we worked for the UNHCR and Alight), chance to work with an incredible professor (Jenna wrote a book related to the research we were doing and was an incredible mentor throughout the entire process). The Capstone also challenged me to think more deeply about what kinds of policy and initiatives are genuinely feasible in an international aid context, and pushed us to home in on what the central issues were within protracted refugee situations and how to communicate proposed solutions. 
Weaknesses: the course should have come with more initial training in methodology, such as how to conduct interviews and how to set up a survey. This prep work could have been facilitated through training sessions by the Jackson Institute, and started over the summer or very early on in the fall semester. Part of this prep could involve bringing in graduate students who have worked on similar research and learning best practices from them.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would. I gained a lot of very valuable work experience and knowledge of protracted refugee situations. It has helped me know what I want to do after I graduate.

Absolutely - it's required for the GLBL major so everyone will end up taking it anyway, but the capstone is one of the most important courses I've taken at Yale. Jenna (our professor) is incredible, and I learned so much from being a part of this team. It was a unique opportunity to take academic interest in foreign policy and development and apply it in a real-world setting.
